key_title: Key to the species of Leptospermum

Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Lyne, A.
source.title: Leptospermum
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Lyne, A. (1996). Leptospermum. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Hypanthium glabrous
Hypanthium villous or silky on at least lower half
Fruit deciduous, the surface glabrous and wrinkled; hypanthium with a pedicel 3–5 mm long
Fruit persistent, the surface glabrous and ultimately shedding in papery flakes; hypanthium with a pedicel up to c. 1 mm long
Leaves pungent, the margins minutely denticulate
Leaves not pungent, the margins entire
Leaves narrowly ovate (broadest near the base and tapering upwards), 1–3.5 mm wide
Leaves narrowly elliptic to almost circular (broadest near the middle and tapering above and below), 2–7 mm wide
Leaves narrow-lanceolate to narrow-elliptic, usually lemon-scented when crushed
Leaves almost circular or obovate, not lemon-scented
Flowers often pinkish; leaves ± circular, mostly 4–7 mm long and wide; fruit 8–12 mm diam.
Flowers white; leaves usually obovate, more than 7 mm long; fruit 5–9 mm diam.

Bark on larger stems smooth, shedding in papery strips; bark on smaller stems shedding in papery flakes; leaves with apex obtuse or obtuse and with a small point; rocky sites in north-eastern subalps and alps
Bark on larger stems fibrous, persistent; bark on smaller stems shedding in stringy strips; leaves with apex obtuse or acute or emarginate; mostly riparian
Flowers often pinkish; leaves ± circular, mostly 4–7 mm long and wide; fruit 8–12 mm diam.
Flowers usually white; leaves elliptic to obovate, at least some leaves usually more than 7 mm long; fruit usually less than 8 mm diam.
Young stems with a groove or flange present near base of petiole; sepals falling from fruit; hypanthium with a pedicel up to c. 1 mm
Young stems without a groove or flange near base of petiole; sepals persisting on fruit; hypanthium sessile
Adult leaves glabrous (rarely with a few appressed silky hairs persisting)
Adult leaves distinctly silky on one or both surfaces
Sepals c. 2 mm long, with a broadly rounded apex
Sepals 3–6.5 mm long, with an acute apex
Flowers c. 15 mm diam.; sepals villous on outer surface; fruit broadly hemispherical
Flowers c. 25 mm diam.; sepals silky on outer surface; fruit obconical
Bark on larger stems smooth, shedding in papery strips; leaves 3–8 mm wide, glabrous and glossy green on upper surface and silky on lower surface or, silky on both surfaces, usually suberect
Bark on larger stems fibrous, persistent; leaves 1.5–4 mm wide, silky on both surfaces and with a silvery sheen, usually spreading
